steps.title: Background
steps.description:
Oh yes ... Judgement ... I've also been known to take "your honor"'s role and swing my mighty condemning hammer from time to time ...

Sometimes it feels like if everyone just listen to us and do as we say, life on this planet would blossom, birds would sing, sun will shine, everything would just "work!" you know?

answers.text: Oh yes I do Adam ... Why wouldn't they listen?
Yes, I've been judging people as well ...
Ok, so what's next?

steps.title: Inherently helpful loved ones
steps.description:
${echo}

I'm sure you, like me, just LOVE when people tell you to inherently helpful things like ...

- *"Just let go!"*
- *"Stop thinking about it!"*
- *"Can't you see it from their point of view??"*

I have not found that to be useful, and often just gives me one more thing to judge!

answers.text: Aahhhh loved ones ... Sometimes you just wanna smother them, don't you?
Actually that never happened to me
OK, so what's next?

steps.title: Judgement Experiences
steps.description:
${echo}

To begin our exploration, think of 2-3 things outside yourself, some persons, acts, or events that you judge as bad, wrong, or evil, "That's wrong!" ...

Got few of those?

(If this is your first time using this tool, don't go for self-judgement, you'll see why later)
steps.notes: *"There is nothing either good or bad, but thinking makes it so"* — Shakespeare

answers.text: Oh yes ... I have some 2-3 good ones in mind ...
Got it, let's continue
Judging? Me? NEVER! I'm a saint! (okay okay, I got a few examples ...)

steps.title: Let go of Letting go
steps.description:
${echo}

I suspect the reason "just let go" doesn't work is it offers no alternative, and there IS a reason we judge.

We may think (or KNOW) there's a better way of doing whatever it is we are judging.

We may have some values that we feel are jeopardized and at danger.

Letting go is not a good idea!

Now before I share with you a trick to transform/expand the judgement for something more useful ...
steps.notes: *"Your task is of altering, not abolishing"* - Milton Erickson

answers.text: Oh yes, I like tricks!
Ok, what's next Adam?
Judgement can be useful? Interesting ...

steps.title: Choose an example your honor!
steps.description:
Pick an experience of judging another person, that you'll be happy to "free yourself" from.

Something like

- *“X is bad/wrong”*
- *"You can't/shouldn't do X"*
steps.notes: E.g. *"Talking to your kids like this is bad"*

steps.title: Judgement to preference
steps.description:
${echo}

Now express the same thing as a preference, something like:

- *"I strongly prefer Y over X"*
- *"I much rather have you do Y over X"*
steps.notes: E.g. *"I much rather you'd talk to your kids in a soft tone of voice"*

steps.title: Judgement to preference - Recovering deleted content
steps.description:
Fantastic!

At this point often times the feelings of judgement are mostly cleared, and as frosting on the cake, see if there's any useful information you'd like to add to the judgement.

For example, let's say I make the judgement "You shouldn't be late!"

Not a lot of information in there, right?

But when we expand that to:

*"I much rather enjoy meeting you in the time we scheduled, when we make plans to go out, so I don't waste time waiting, so I know you care about my time, and I feel respected instead of underrated."*

Now there's a more complete/encompassing picture of what I feel, what I want, when I feel it, why I feel it, and in relation to what/who.

So take the initial statement you made:  
*"${s4}"*

That you already expressed as a preference: *"${s5}"*

And add any information that might be relevant, to get a more complete experience (Don't be cheap now, the more the merrier!)

steps.title: Bring forth the defendant! - Gender
steps.description:
For an even more complete resolution, here's something to play with ...

The poor soul you've judged, is he/she a male or female?

answers.text: Male
Female

steps.title: Bow before the all mighty judge
steps.description: And what is your own name, your honor?

steps.title: Take “Other” Position
steps.description:
In a moment I'll ask you to jump into ${s11}'s POV (point of view) and recall that past statement you made:  
*"${s4}"*

And literally relive the experience thru ${s11}'s eyes, so you see what ${he10} sees, hear what ${he10} hears, and act like ${he10} acts.

From this POV, think of your limitations that make you act this way, and feel ${s12}'s judgement descending upon you in all it's might and glory, judging you, your puny little actions, and your limitations.

Close your eyes and do it now.

answers.text: Yikes! That was NOT fun!
Oh Adam ... I've tasted my own medicine and it is bitter ...
Done reliving the judgement thru ${s11}'s eyes

steps.title: Take “Other” Position - Preference
steps.description:
Now I want you to do the same thing, and this time as you relive the experience, feel the difference when instead of judging, ${s12} is telling you the following ...

*"${s5}"*

Close your eyes and do it now

answers.text: Oh my, what a difference!
OK Adam, I get your point, no more judging for me!
That was interesting ...

steps.title: Reliving as preference
steps.description:
Now go back to your POV and relive the experience thru your own eyes, describing your full preference to ${s11} instead of your old judgement.

Notice how the situation is different, and how you feel being this way now.

Close your eyes and do it now.

answers.text: I feel much better being this way!
I notice ${s11} prefers this over my past judgments
The entire situation has improved greatly

steps.title: Future pacing sharing preferences
steps.description:
Now think of some similar future scenarios, in which you would have acted with judgement in the past, and feel the difference in your own and others' responses and emotions, as you share your full preference, and allow this was of being to unfold ...

Close your eyes and do it now ...

answers.text: Yup, this is much better than my old way of thinking
I ran it in my mind with ${s11} as well as other people
This is great! I can feel my relationships improving greatly

description: Transform bad feelings of judgement to resourceful ACTIONABLE preference
title: Judgement to Preference
